page.title: 02Local History-East Leicester
page.content: Occupation of the western part of the block began around 100 years ago with the building of small terraced houses for railway and factory workers & more substantial Victorian villas. The area owes much to the architect{Arthur {Wakerley}(1862-1931) of Crown Hills House. His plan for a parallel town to Leicester resulted in the building of a fire station,police station,market hall & square,a Wesley Hall Chapel,The Imperial Temperance Hotel,workers houses (Â£299),cottages & workshops for the blind,all in the North Evington area. By 1945 much of the central block had been developed with 1930's semis & council housing but large areas of farmland,with a few mansion houses,extended to the east. Today this part of the block is much changed. Centrally many more factories have been built.{(continued page 3)
